metadata.case_name: Appellant (Land Development Company) v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The appellant deals in land and property and carries on land developing business; buys land, develops it by laying out roads, providing drainage system, installing street lights, maintains them till taken over by Municipality, then sells in plots at profit.

Developments are carried out before land is sold; whole sale price not received in cash at time of sale; purchaser pays 25% in cash, balance with interest in ten annual installments secured by charge on land.

Appellant undertakes to carry out developments within six months from sale date, but time not of essence; to be done within reasonable time; undertaking in deed of sale, security by separate document.

In accounting year for assessment year 1948-49, appellant sold plots; received Rs. 29,392-11-9 in cash; full sale price Rs. 43,692-11-9 credited in books under mercantile system; balance Rs. 14,300 unpaid, secured by charge plus interest.
Appellant estimated Rs. 24,809 as expenditure for developments on sold plots; debited in books as liability accrued, though no actual expenditure made.
Appellant maintains accounts on mercantile method: credits due/receivable amounts, debits accrued liabilities before actual receipt/disbursement.
Income-tax Officer disallowed deduction of Rs. 24,809 as expenses not actually incurred and estimate not based on real expenses.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed disallowance: no accrued liability, development future, estimate at current prices not allowable.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held actual cost uncertain, expenses deductible only when incurred; dismissed appeal.
Tribunal referred question to High Court under s.66(1): Whether Rs. 24,809 legally allowable as expense of the year.
Calcutta High Court criticized Tribunal's case statement as sketchy; answered question in negative.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 135 Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.
Developments specified: construct roads, pucca surface drains, lighting, maintain till Municipality takeover; fill low lands and tanks to road level at own cost.
Appellant led evidence on estimated expenditure Rs. 24,809; no exception to quantum, only to permissibility.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to deduction of Rs. 24,809 estimated for developments in computation of profits for 1948-49, under mercantile system where full sale price credited though partly unpaid.
Whether the liability for developments is accrued or contingent.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under mercantile system accepted by ITO, full receipts credited including unpaid balance; corresponding liability for developments accrued and deductible even without actual disbursement.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mercantile system as in Keshav Mills Ltd. v. CIT; s.10(1) and s.10(2)(xv) Income-tax Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Undertaking in deeds of sale creates absolute liability to develop within reasonable time; estimate proper debit.

respondent_arguments.text: Expenses not actually incurred; cost uncertain; no accrued liability, only contingent; deductible only when incurred.
Deduction only under specific provisions of s.10(2); no preliminary deduction under general principles.

court_reasoning.text: Mercantile system credits due amounts before receipt, debits accrued liabilities before disbursement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: System explained in Keshav Mills Ltd. v. CIT.

court_reasoning.text: Liability unconditional and absolute in deeds; accrued on sale date though discharge future; not contingent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Time not essence; purchasers can enforce.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Peter Merchant: there contingent on claim; here absolute undertaking.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accrued liability deductible even if estimated.

court_reasoning.text: Estimation difficulty does not make contingent; ITO can scrutinize estimate as in Gold Coast Selection Trust.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Value liability at accounting period end.

court_reasoning.text: Profits/gains under s.10(1) require deducting necessary expenditure/obligations against receipts, per commercial sense; s.10(2) not exhaustive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Russell v. Town Bank, Gresham Life, Chitnavis, Badridas Daga.

court_reasoning.text: Rs. 24,809 incidental to business, allowable under s.10(1); evidence on quantum accepted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revenue inconsistent in accepting full receipts but rejecting debit.

holdings.text: Rs. 24,809 is deductible as accrued liability under mercantile system in computing profits under s.10(1) Income-tax Act.
Liability accrued, not contingent; estimate allowable with scrutiny.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
Peter Merchant Ltd. v. Stedeford Inspector of Taxes
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishes actual vs. contingent liability; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gold Coast Selection Trust Ltd. v. Humphrey Inspector of Taxes
precedents_cited.relevance: Valuation of unrealizable assets/liabilities at accounting end.

precedents_cited.case_name: Russell v. Town and County Bank, Ltd.
Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles
precedents_cited.relevance: Profits ascertained by setting expenditures/obligations against receipts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras

precedents_cited.relevance: Account for losses to arrive at true profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: s.10(2) not exhaustive; deductions per commercial practice under s.10(1).

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Computation of business profits; allowable deductions; reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court from High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; referred question answered in affirmative: Rs. 24,809 deductible.
outcome.relief_granted: Deduction of Rs. 24,809 allowed in assessment for 1948-49.

key_quotes.text: The mercantile system of accounting... brings into credit what is due, immediately it becomes legally due... and brings into debit expenditure the amount for which a legal liability has been incurred before it is actually disbursed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines mercantile accounting principle central to decision.

key_quotes.text: The profit of a trade or business is the surplus by which the receipts... exceed the expenditure necessary for the purpose of earning those receipts.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains commercial meaning of profits under s.10(1).

key_quotes.text: When a claim is made for a deduction for which there is no specific provision in s.10(2), whether it is admissible... will depend on whether... it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the business and to be incidental to it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Badridas Daga; allows deduction under s.10(1).
